poem:
The Locksmith's Lament  

In the yawning keyhole of morning,  
a snapped key breaks the quiet,  
and the babysitter rings a number—  
a voice promising rescue for £49.  
But the clink of deceit echoes,  
as the locksmith whispers of failure,  
and numbers climb like ivy at dusk.  
The door, just another metaphor,  
for what we let strangers unlock.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I was charged £1,406 after my key snapped in my door’: how to protect against locksmith fraud A key snapped in the lock as my son and his young babysitter tried to open my front door. The babysitter searched online and called a locksmith quoting a £49 call-out charge. The locksmith claimed the key could not be extracted and insisted the entire locking mechanism had failed and would need to be repaired at his workshop,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
